headline: Staff Picks From the Book Review
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Almost half of the authors we recommend this week are dead, which is bad luck for them but further proof that books can live long past their writers — millenniums past in some cases, as in Sun Tzu’s timeless guide “The Art of War,” at the top of our list in a new translation. Also dead, also translated: the Croatian novelist Dasa Drndic (1946-2018), whose work began getting its due in English toward the end of her life; her latest to arrive on these shores is “Doppelgänger.” Then we have a couple of posthumous collections: stories by Larry Brown (1951-2004) and essays by Brian Doyle (1956-2017), all of them pulsing with life.
